name: Gift Certificates !!!
description: Not sure what to get? Gift Certificates make great gifts! Can be used online or in person at an upcoming show.

name: Eilat Dreidel
description:
Have fun playing dreidel this season with a beautiful Eilat Dreidel. It is fabricated in pewter and brass and has embossed Hebrew Letters. A dreidel has one Hebrew letter on each side. Outside of Israel, those letters are: נ (Nun), ג (Gimmel), ה (Hay) and ש (Shin), which stand for the Hebrew phrase "Nes Gadol Haya Sham." This phrase means "A great miracle happened there [in Israel]."

Style # 155

<meta name="google-site-verification" content="aQULS9s0q-_MohCLtYAyPsqTJ3zHx6yc62l5dXJBM0o" />

name: Negev Menorah
description:
Inspired by my trip to Israel in January of 2010. It is my interpretation of the hills I saw looking out over the Negev desert. It is made from fabricated pewter with two panels of large pebble texture elevated on either side of the form. Nine sold brass candle holders are affixed to the base. 

Dimensions: 10.25" x 2.75" x 4"

Style # 132

name: Full Pattern Dreidel
description:
This decorative dreidel is made using a technique of scoring and folding sheets of pewter. The texture is roll-printed using a rolling mill and the pieces are soldered together using a lead-free low-temperature solder. The other elements are made from brass.

Dimensions: 4" x 2.125" x 2.125"

Style #114

name: Modern Geometric Pewter Menorah
description:
Simplify Hanukkah with this stunning contemporary geometric pewter and brass menorah. It has long clean lines with half-ball sold brass cups to hold the candles.

6"H x 10" W X  2" D

name: Wedding Shard Candle Holders
description:
Custom Engraving available! These beautiful candle holders are a perfect gift for the newly married couple so they can place their own broken glass inside and remember that joyful moment under the chuppah, when the groom broke the glass and the guests all shouted "Mazel Tov". Here is an opportunity to create a family heirloom using their crushed shards. They stand 4.5" tall and 1.5" wide. The square tube is made from acrylic and the top and bottom out of pewter. They come with two sets of interchangeable inserts, one fits shabbos candles and another that will fit a standard tapered candle. Style # 168-000 Please Allow 2 Weeks for production delivery

description:

10" x 10" x 2"

name: Salt Shaker with Hamotzi
description:
This beautiful salt shaker is fabricated from pewter and brass and has on it the Hamotzi or blessing over the challah. According to Jewish law and practice, salting Challah is a critical component of HaMotzi, the blessing over bread. Salt has always played an indispensable role in Jewish life and ritual dating back to the biblical period of ancient Israel. With high quantities located in the Dead Sea region of the historical land of the Jewish people, salt was considered the most essential and common of all elements. Dimensions: 4" x 1.5" x 1.5" Style # 131-P Can also be ordered in any of the 8 textures.

name: Frumma Tzedakah Box
description:
Inspire Jewish generosity by giving Joy Stember Judaica! Named after my Mother, Fran, who is the most generous person I know, this tzedakah box is fabricated from pewter and brass the letters are hand pierced. The top is hinged to remove the money to give to charity. Dimensions: 5" H x 2.75" W x 1.75" D Style # 167 Your piece will come in a white box with the Joy Stember Logo, bio and care instructions. GIFT WRAP AND CARD AVAILABLE! In Judaism, tzedakah refers to the religious obligation to do what is right and just, which Judaism emphasizes are important parts of living a spiritual life. In practice, most Jews carry out tzedakah by donating a portion of their income to charitable institutions. A Tzedakah box is used to collect that money and keep it safe until it is given to charity.

name: I am My Beloved Wedding Cup
description:
Makes a perfect wedding present!

I am my beloved and my beloved is mine script from Solomon's Song is embossed onto the sides of this very special goblet. The finish denotes antiquity and the shape shows the essence of contemporary life. 

The base can be engraved with the couples names and wedding dates Please call for engraving prices!

Style # 148-P

name: Pyramid Havdalah Spice Box
description:
Havdalah is a ritual that takes place at the end of Shabbat. Just as candles are lit to welcome Shabbat on Friday evenings, havdalah (Hebrew for “separation”) marks the end of Shabbat and separates it from regular weekdays. According to Jewish legend, we each receive an extra soul that makes us especially attuned to the spiritual world during Shabbat. This soul leaves when Shabbat is over and the smell of spices is meant to revive us as it departs. 

This Spice box is fabricated from pewter and brass. The lid is hinged in the back with a brass hinge. The front is adorned with a brass hand-pierced Star of David. 

Style #153

name: Cast Yad with Rutilated Quartz Point
description:
This torah pointer is cast from pewter and has a tip of Rutilated quartz. This stone is very special because each one is different. Rutile often forms needle-like crystal inclusions inside quartz.  This form of quartz is known as rutilated quartz and it looks like small bars of imbedded gold. 
Formed to fit perfectly in your hand, allowing your index finger to comfortable rest on the top edge.

Custom engraving available!

Style # 154

name: Rutilated Quartz Yad
description:
A Yad is used by the reader to follow the text during the Torah reading from the parchment Torah scrolls. The Yad ensures that the parchment is not touched during the reading because it is often-fragile and is easily damaged.

This exquisite Yad is fabricated from pewter, brass and rutilated quartz. It bends at the tip as a knuckle might. Perfect size for an adult reader. Can be special ordered with a chain. Call for quotes!

Rutilated Quartz: A variety of quartz with inclusions of rutile crystals, which are minerals that sometimes appear in a needle-like fashion in a reddish-brown to red and sometimes yellowish appearance.

Style # 151

name: Rectangular Tzedakah Box
description:
In Judaism, tzedakah refers to the religious obligation to do what is right and just, which Judaism emphasizes are important parts of living a spiritual life. In practice, most Jews carry out tzedakah by donating a portion of their income to charitable institutions. A Tzedakah box is used to collect that money and keep it safe until it is given to charity. This square Tzedakah box is fabricated from pewter and brass. The top lifts up to remove the money. Dimensions: 5" x 2" x 3" Style #142

name: Pesach Plate
description:
Passover commemorates the story of the Exodus, in which the ancient Israelites were freed from slavery in Egypt. It is celebrated for seven or eight days and is one of the most widely observed Jewish holidays. Each of the six items arranged on the plate has special significance to the retelling of the story of the exodus from Egypt, which is the focus of this ritual meal. 

This plate comes with a solid brass base that has circular holes cut from it for the cups to sit in. Also allowing the cups to be removable. The cups are made from pewter and havehand-pierced pewter Hebrew words representing the ceremonial foods that go on a traditional Passover plate. 

Dimensions: 12" x 12", 3.5" cups

Style # 115-B

Those words are:
Maror and chazeret — Bitter herbs, symbolizing the bitterness and harshness of the slavery which the Hebrews endured in Egypt. Either horseradish or romaine lettuce may be eaten in fulfillment of the mitzvah of eating bitter herbs during the Seder.

Charoset — A sweet, brown mixture representing the mortar used by the Jewish slaves to build the storehouses of Egypt. In Ashkenazi Jewish homes, charoset is traditionally made from chopped nuts, grated apples, cinnamon, and sweet red wine. Sephardi recipes call for dates and honey in addition to chopped nuts, cinnamon, and wine.

Karpas — A vegetable other than bitter herbs, which is dipped into salt water at the beginning of the Seder. Parsley, celery or boiled potato is usually used. The dipping of a simple vegetable into salt water (which represents tears) mirrors the pain felt by the Hebrew slaves in Egypt. Usually in a Shabbat or holiday meal, the first thing to be eaten after the kiddush over wine is bread. At the Seder table, however, the first thing to be eaten after the kiddush is a vegetable. This leads immediately to the recital of the famous question, Ma Nishtana — "Why is this night different from all other nights?" It also symbolizes the spring time, because Jews celebrate Passover in the spring.

Z'roa — Also called Zeroah, it is special as it is the only element of meat on the Seder Plate.[1] A roasted lamb or goat shankbone, chicken wing, or chicken neck; symbolizing the korban Pesach (Pesach sacrifice), which was a lamb that was offered in the Temple in Jerusalem, then roasted and eaten as part of the meal on Seder night. Since the destruction of the Temple, the z'roa serves as a visual reminder of the Pesach sacrifice; it is not eaten or handled during the Seder. Vegetarians often substitute a beet, quoting Pesachim 114b as justification.

Beitzah — A hard-boiled egg, symbolizing the korban chagigah (festival sacrifice) that was offered in the Temple in Jerusalem and roasted and eaten as part of the meal on Seder night. Although both the Pesach sacrifice and the chagigah were meat offerings, the chagigah is commemorated by an egg, a symbol of mourning (as eggs are the first thing served to mourners after a funeral), evoking the idea of mourning over the destruction of the Temple and our inability to offer any kind of sacrifices in honor of the Pesach holiday. Since the destruction of the Temple, the beitzah serves as a visual reminder of the chagigah; it is not used during the formal part of the seder, but some people eat it with saltwater as the first course of the meal.

name: Havdalah Candle Holder
description:
This candle holder is made from pewter and brass then fabricated using a lead free soft solder. The texture is roll printed using a rolling mill. Dimensions: 2.75" x 2.75" x 1.75" Style # 110 PLEASE ALLOW 2-4 WEEKS FOR DELIVERY

name: Yad
description:
This handmade one-of-a-kind fabricated pewter torah pointer is an unique example of a contemporary Judaica. The tip is a piece of meteorite that was found in the shape of a pointing finger. 

Dimensions: 11" x 4" x 2"

Style # 117

name: JS Metal Arts Studio T-Shirt
description: Show your support for your favorite local metalsmith with this Hanes Tagless T-shirt in Black and white
